==Preventive actions==
==Preventive actions==

=== Palestine ===

==== West Bank ====
''[[Haaretz]]'' suggested that an announcement by the [[Palestinian Authority]] on 1 February to hold [[Palestinian local elections, 2011|municipal elections in July]] is in reaction to the anti-government protests in Egypt. PA municipal, legislative and presidential elections were [[Palestinian local elections, 2004â2005|last held in 2004â2005]], [[Palestinian legislative election, 2006|2006]], and [[Palestinian presidential election, 2005|2005]], respectively, leaving the president and members of parliament in office after their elected terms had ended.<ref>{{cite web|last=Associated |first=The |url=http://www.haaretz.com/news/diplomacy-defense/palestinian-government-calls-for-local-elections-amid-egypt-unrest-1.340595 |title=Palestinian government calls for local elections amid Egypt unrest - Haaretz Daily Newspaper | Israel News |publisher=Haaretz.com |date=2010-02-06 |accessdate=2011-02-02}}</ref> Palestinian prime minister [[Salam Fayyad]] admitted that the protests had changed his mind about elections, which he had previously seen as divisive, and views the short-term unrest as a trend toward long-term 'positive change' in the Arab world's politics.<ref name="nytimespapm">{{cite news|last=Saltmarsh|first=Matthew|title=Palestinian Premier Sees 'Positive Change' in Unrest|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/02/05/world/middleeast/05iht-fayyad05.html|work=NYTimes.com|publisher=The New York Times|accessdate=5 February 2011}}</ref> An aide to President Abbas said that the Palestinians will hold a [[Palestinian general election, 2011|election]] by September,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nytimes.com/aponline/2011/02/12/world/middleeast/AP-ML-Israel-Palestinians.html?_r=1&ref=news |title=Palestinians to Hold Elections |publisher=Nytimes.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-13}}</ref> however the move was immediately condemned by [[Hamas]] who said they would boycott the election.
''[[Haaretz]]'' suggested that an announcement by the [[Palestinian Authority]] on 1 February to hold [[Palestinian local elections, 2011|municipal elections in July]] is in reaction to the anti-government protests in Egypt. PA municipal, legislative and presidential elections were [[Palestinian local elections, 2004â2005|last held in 2004â2005]], [[Palestinian legislative election, 2006|2006]], and [[Palestinian presidential election, 2005|2005]], respectively, leaving the president and members of parliament in office after their elected terms had ended.<ref>{{cite web|last=Associated |first=The |url=http://www.haaretz.com/news/diplomacy-defense/palestinian-government-calls-for-local-elections-amid-egypt-unrest-1.340595 |title=Palestinian government calls for local elections amid Egypt unrest - Haaretz Daily Newspaper | Israel News |publisher=Haaretz.com |date=2010-02-06 |accessdate=2011-02-02}}</ref> Palestinian prime minister [[Salam Fayyad]] admitted that the protests had changed his mind about elections, which he had previously seen as divisive, and views the short-term unrest as a trend toward long-term 'positive change' in the Arab world's politics.<ref name="nytimespapm">{{cite news|last=Saltmarsh|first=Matthew|title=Palestinian Premier Sees 'Positive Change' in Unrest|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/02/05/world/middleeast/05iht-fayyad05.html|work=NYTimes.com|publisher=The New York Times|accessdate=5 February 2011}}</ref> An aide to President Abbas said that the Palestinians will hold a [[Palestinian general election, 2011|election]] by September,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nytimes.com/aponline/2011/02/12/world/middleeast/AP-ML-Israel-Palestinians.html?_r=1&ref=news |title=Palestinians to Hold Elections |publisher=Nytimes.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-13}}</ref> however the move was immediately condemned by [[Hamas]] who said they would boycott the election.
